title: Metaphorical Reality: Michael Vincent Di Fuccia discusses the Gift of Meaning and the Middle Voice
description:
In Karen's absence, our Michael interviews Michael Vincent Di Fuccia, author of Owen Barfield: Philosophy, Poetry and Theology, a major contribution to the study of Owen Barfield.                                                                     

The discussion included mentions of:
Adrian Pabst, Metaphysics: the Creation of Hierarchy
John Milbank:  Founder of the Radical Orthodoxy movement
Catherine Pickstock: On the Liturgical Consummation of Philosophy
Irish poet, David White

God is beyond Being, and yet, in us.
Inimical vs. equivoal
Secularism arose from bad theology in the middle Ages
Theresa.of Avila - the third stage.
Nicholas of Cusa - reaching the point of not knowing.

Reason reaches and end and in that moment of grace, reason is perfected by faith.
A deeper understanding of God that causes us to unlearn and simultaneously lear new, deeper truths that become a part of who we are.
David Schindler
David Harper
The fundamental question, a question of wonder.
Why is there something rather than nothing?
The middle voice
Pheomenology (Heidegger)
Post-modernity = passivity - the passive subject
In Greek there is a middle voice between active and passive and it is always theurgic in the Greek. Something to do with the connection to the divine.
Barfield translates phenomenon in the middle voice. Paul often talks of prayer in the middle voice.
Icons suspend idolatry because we learn to see through them.

What does Christianity have to offer? Humility, a vision of unknowing.
You can learn a lot about God by attending to reality.
The link to the imagination has something to do with moving us toward the "final participation" Barfield talks about.
Free will v. God's sovereignty?  We do play a role, and also, God is sovereign

Coleridge
Imagination is reason in her most exalted mood.
Prose is the words in the best order. Poetry is the best words in the best order.
The concept of gift is fundamental to Christianity. 
Not "MINE" (like Gollum, a place of idolatry), but "This is a gift from our gracious God."
Learning to see things as gifts from the Creator rather than "givens".
